description: Number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population, by sex, age and key populations

institutional_information.label: Organization(s)
institutional_information.content: The Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS)

definition.label: Definition
definition.content: The number of new HIV infections per 1,000 uninfected population, by sex, age and key populations as defined as the number of new HIV infections per 1000 person-years among the uninfected population.

rationale.label: Rationale
rationale.content: The incidence rate provides a measure of progress toward preventing onward transmission of HIV.

computation_method.label: Computation Method
computation_method.content: Longitudinal data on individuals are the best source of data but are rarely available for large populations. Special diagnostic tests in surveys or from health facilities can be used to obtain data on HIV incidence. HIV incidence is thus modelled using the Spectrum software.

disaggregation.label: Disaggregation
disaggregation.content: General population, Key populations (men who have sex with men, sex workers, people who inject drugs, transgender people, prisoners), Age groups (0-14, 15-24, 15-49, 50+ years), for key populations (< 25, 25+ years), mode of transmission (including mother-to-child transmission), place of residence, sex

treatment_of_missing_values_at_country_l.label: Treatment of missing values at country level
treatment_of_missing_values_at_country_l.content: Data are not compiled for countries with populations < 250,000. In addition no estimates are available for about 10 countries with very small HIV epidemics or countries in conflict (i.e. Syria). These countries are excluded from global estimates.

treatment_of_missing_values_at_regional_.label: Treatment of missing values at regional and global levels
treatment_of_missing_values_at_regional_.content: Missing countries are excluded from the estimates.

regional_aggregates.label: Regional aggregates
regional_aggregates.content: The software used to produce the estimates is Spectrum�developed by Avenir Health (www.avenirhealth.org)�and the Estimates and Projections Package, which is developed by the East-West Center (www.eastwestcenter.org). The UNAIDS Reference Group on Estimates, Modelling and Projections provides technical guidance on the development of the HIV component of the software (www.epidem.org).

sources_of_discrepancies.label: Sources of discrepancies
sources_of_discrepancies.content: These variations will differ by country.

description.label: Description
description.content:
Spectrum modelling, household or key population surveys with HIV incidence-testing,
Other possible data sources: Regular surveillance system among key populations.

collection_process.label: Collection process
collection_process.content: Country teams use UNAIDS-supported software to develop estimates annually. The country teams are comprised of primarily epidemiologists, demographers, monitoring and evaluation specialists and technical partners.

data_collection.label: Data collection
data_collection.content: Data sources are compiled all year long. The spectrum models are created in the first three months of every year and finalized by June. The next report will be in June 2017.

data_providers.label: Data providers
data_providers.content: The estimates are produced by a team consisting of ministry of health, national AIDS advisory groups and development partners. The results are signed off on by senior managers at the ministries of health.

other.label: Other
other.content:
